MassString¶

class isopy.MassString(string)[source]¶

String representation of an integer representing a mass number.

The supplied string must consist only of digits. MassString can also be initialised with an integer.

Behaves just like, and contains all the methods that, a normal python string does. However, any method that returns a string will return a normal python string and not an MassString unless specifically noted below. Only methods that behave differently from a normal string are documented below.

The MassString will behave as an integer when used with the ==, !=, <, <=, > and >= operators. If used in conjunction with a string it will be converted to a float before the operation.

Can be made into an RatioString using the / operator and an IsotopeString using the + operator.

Raises

  • StringParseError – Is raised when the supplied string cannot be parsed into the correct format

  • StringTypeError – Raised when the supplied item cannot be turned into a string

Examples

>>> isopy.MassString('76')
'76'
>>> isopy.MassString(70)
'70'

Comparisons

>>> isopy.MassString('76') == 76
True
>>> isopy.MassString('76') == '76'
True
>>> isopy.MassString('76') != 76
False

Using + and /

>>> isopy.MassString('76') / 'ge'
'76/Ge'
>>> 'ge' / isopy.MassString('76')
'Ge/76'
>>> 'ge' + isopy.MassString('76')
'76Ge'
>>> isopy.MassString('76') + 'ge'
'76Ge'

Using <, <=, > and >=

>>> isopy.MassString('76') > 70
True
>>> isopy.MassString('76') <= '76'
True
identifier()[source]¶

Returns descriptive identifier that can be used to e.g. name attributes.

The returned string can be parsed back into an MassString the same as any other string.

Examples

>>> isopy.MassString(76).identifier()
'Mass_76'
>>> isopy.MassString('Mass_76')
'76'
Returns

A string that can be used as a variable name

Return type

str
